Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: He wolde suffre for a quart of wyne
A good felowe to haue his concubyne
A twelf monthe and excuse hym atte fulle
Ful priuyly ek a fynche couthe he pulle
And if he fonde owhere a goode felawe
He wolde techen hym to haue noon awe
In sich cas of the erchedekenes curs
But if mannes soule were in his purs
For in his purs he shulde punyshid be
Purs is the erchedekenes helle seide he
But wel I wote he lied riȝt in dede
Of cursing ouȝt ech gylty man hym drede
For curs wole sle right as assoyling sauith
And also ware hym of a signyficauit
In daunger hadde he at his owne gise
Tho yonge gerles of the diocise
And knewe her councel and what was al her rede
A garland hadde he sette vppon his heede
As gret as it were for an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made him of a cake
¶ With him ther rode a gentyl pardoner
Of Rouncevale his frend ⁊and his comper
That streight was comen fro þe court of Rome
Ful loude songe he come hidir to me loue come
This somynour bar to hym a stif burdoun
Was neuere trumpe of half so greet a sown
This pardoner hadde heer as yelow as wax
But smothe it henge as doth a stryk of flax
By ounces henge his lokkis that he hadde
And therwith he his shuldris ouerspradde
But thynne it lay by colpoıı̄uns oon ⁊and oon
But hoode for Iolite weride he noon
For it was trussed up in his walet
Hym thought he rode al of the newe get
Discheuele saf his cappe roode al bare
Sich glaring eyghen hadde he as an hare
A vernycle hadde he sewid uppon his cappe .
His walet biforne hym in his lappe .
Bretful of pardoun comen fro Rome al hote
A voys he hadde as smal as a gote
No berd hadde he ne neuere shulde haue
As smothe it was as it were late shaue
I trowe he were a gelding or a mare
But of his craft fro berwyk into ware
Ne was ther sich another pardoner
For in his male he hadde a pilowbere
Which that he seide was oure lady veyle
He seide he hadde a gobet of the seylke
That seynt petir hadde whanne that he wente .
Vppon the see til ihıı̄un crist hym hente
He hadde a Croys of latoun ful of stones
And in a glas he hadde pigges bones
But with these whanne that he fonde
A pouer persoıı̄unx dwellinge vppon londe
Vppon a day he gat he gat hym more moneye
Than the persoıı̄un gat in monthes tweye
And thus with feyned flatering ⁊and Iapes
He made the pesoıı̄un and the puple his apes
But trewly to tellen atte the laste
He was in chirche a noble ecciaste .
Wel couthe he rede a lessoıı̄un or a storye
But alther best he songe an offertorye
For wel he wiste whanne that song was songe
He most preche and wel affile his tonge
To wynne siluer as he wel cowde
Therfore he song so merily and lowde
Now haue I tolde yow sothly in a clause
The estat the array the nombre ⁊and ek the cause
Why that assemblid was this companye
In southwerk at this gentil hosterie
That hight the tabbard fast by the belle
But now is tyme to yow for to telle
How that we beren vs that ilk nyght
Whanne we were in that Osterie a lyght
And aftir wole I tellen of oure viage
And al the remenaunt of oure pilgrimage
But first I preye yow of youre curtesye
That ye ne rette it not my vylonye
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To tellen yow her wordis and her chere
Ne though I speke her wordis ꝓpropurly
For this ye knowen as wel as I .
Who so shal tellen a tale aftir a man
He moot reherce as nygh as euer he kan
Euerich a word if it be in his charge
Al speke he neuere so rudely ⁊and large
Or elles he moot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thingis or fynde wordis newe
He may nought spare al though he were his brother
He mote also wel seie o word as an oþer
Crist spak hym self ful brode in holy writt
And wel ȝe wote no velonye is itte
Eke plato seith who so kan hym rede
The wordes mot be Cosyn to the dede
Also I preye yow foryeue it me
Al haue I not sett folk in her degre
Heere in this tale as that they shulde stonde
My witt is short ye may wel vndirstonde
Gret chere made oure Ost vs euerichon
And to the soꝑper/par sette he us anoon
He seruyde us with vitayles atte the beste
Strong was the wyne and wel drynke us leste
A semely man oure Ost was with alle
Forto ben a marchall in an halle
A large man he was with yghen stepe
A fairer burgeys is noon in chepe
Bolde of his speche and wys ⁊and wel taught
And of manhode hym lakkide right nought
Eke therto he was right a mery man
And aftir soper pleyn he bygan .
And spak of mirthe among and othere thingis
Whanne that he hadde mad oure rykenynges
And seide thus now lordyngis trewly
Ye ben to me welcome ryght hertily
For certis yf that I shal not lye
I sawe nought this yere so mery a companye
At ones in this herborowe as it now
Fayn wolde I don you myrthe wiste I how
And of a myrthe I am right now bithought
To don yow ese and it shal coste nought
Ye gon to Caunterbery god yow spede
The blisfull martir quyte you youre mede
And wel I wote as ye gon by the weye
Ye schapen yow to talen and to pleye
For truly comfort ne mirthe is noon
To riden by the weye doumbe as a stoon
And therfore wole y maken you disport
As I seide arst and don yow som comfort .
And if yow liketh alle by oon assent
Forto stonden att my Iuggement
And forto werken as I shal yow seye
To morowe whanne ye riden by the weye
Now so god saue me at my most nede
But ye be merie I wole yeue yow myn heede
Holde up youre hondis withoute more speche
Oure councel was not long forto seche
Vs thought it was not worth to make to wys
And grauntide hym withouten more avys.
And bade hym seie his verdoit as hym liste
Lordlyngis qd he herkeneth now for the beste
But take it nought I praie ȝow in disdeigne
This is the poynt to speke short and pleigne
That eche of yow to short with oure weye
In this viage shal telle tales tweþe
To caunterbury ward I mene it so
And homward he shal tellen other two
Of auentoures that haue bifalle
And which of yow that berith hym best of alle
That is to seyn that tellith in this cas
Tales of best sentence and moost solas
Shal haue a souper at oure aldercost
Here in this place sittynge bi this post
Whāmne that we comen ageyn fro Cauntirbury
And forto make yow the more myry
I wole my siluen goodly with ȝou ride
Right at myn owne caste and be youre gyde
And who so wole my iugement withseye
Shal paye al that we spende by the weye
And if ye vouche saaf that it be so
Telle me anoon without ony word moo
And I wole erly shape me therfore
This thing was graunted ⁊and oure othes swore
With ful glad herte and preien him also
That he wolde vouche saaf forto do soo
And that he wolde be oure gouernour
And of oure tales Iugge and reportour
And sette a soper / at a certeyn prys
And we wolen reuled ben at youre deuys
In high and logh and thus by oon assent
We ben acordid to the Iuggement
And theruppon the wyn was fet anoon
We dronken and to rest wente echon
Withouten ony lenger tariyng
A morow whanne the day gan to springe
Vp roos oure oost and was oure alde cok
And gaderede us to gidr in a flok
And forth we riden a litil more than pas
Onto the watering of seynt Thomas
And there oure oost gan his hors areste
And seide lordis herkeneth if yow leste
Ye wote youre forward and I it yow recorde
If euensong and morowe song accorde
Let se now who shal telle the firste tale
As euere mote I drynke wyn or ale
Who so rebelle to my Iuggement
Shal paye for all that by the weye is spent
Now drawith Cutt er that ye ferther /twynne
Which that hath the shortest shal bigynne
¶ Sir knyght qd he my maister / and my lord
Now drawith Cutt for that is accord
Cometh nere qd he my lady prioresse
And ye sir clerk lat be youre shamfastnesse
Ne studieth noght leye hond to euery man
Anoon to drawe euery wight bigan .
And shortly forto tellen as it was
Were it by auenture or by sort or cas
The sothe is the Cutt fel to the knyght
Of which ful blythe and glad was euery wight
And tellen he most his tale as it was resoun
By forward and by composicioun
As ye han herd what nedith wordes moo
And whanne this gode man sawe that it was soo
As he that wys was and obedient
To kepen his forward by his fre assent
He seide sithen I shal bigynne the game
What welcome be the Cut a goddis name .
Now lat us ride and herkneth what I seie
And with that word we riden forth oure weye
And he bigan with riȝt a mery chere
His tale anoon and seide as ye may heere

hi.hi: Iamque domos patrias scithie post prelia gentis . Prelia laurigero et cetera

div.l: ¶ Heere endith the prolog of this book ;
(base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
(base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May
(base) That Emelye / that fairer was to seene
(base) Than is the lilie / vpon his stalke greene
(base) And fressher than the May / with floures newe
(base) For with the Rose colour stroof hir hewe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I noot which was / the fairer of hem two
(base) Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
(base) She was arysen / and al redy dight
(base) For May wol haue / no slogardye a nyght
(base) The sesoun pryketh / euery gentil herte
(base) And maketh it out of his sleep to sterte
(base) And seith arys / and do thyn obseruance
(base) This maketh Emelye / haue remembrance
(base) To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
(base) Yclothed was she fressh / for to deuyse
(base) Hir yelow heer / was broyded in a tresse
(base) Bihynde hir bak a yerde long I gesse
(base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste
(base) She walketh vp and doun / and as hir liste
(base) She gadreth floures / party white and rede
(base) To make / a subtil gerland for hir hede
(base) And as an Aungel / heuenysshly she soong
(base) ¶ The grete tour / that was so thikke and strong
(base) Which of the Castel / was the chief dongeoun
(base) Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoun
(base) Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shal
(base) Was euene ioynant to the gardyn wal
(base) Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyyng
(base) Bright was the sonne / and cleer / in that mornyng
(base) And Palamon / this woful prisoner
(base) As was his wone / by leue of his Gailler
(base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro

div.l: (base) On huntyng be they riden roially

div.l: (base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn

(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus

div.l: (base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun

div.l: (base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde

(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge

(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there

(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some

div.l: (base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee

(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys

(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge

(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne

(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was

(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon

div.l: (base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee

(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down

(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue

(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf

(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere

div.l: (base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances

(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon

(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye

(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al

(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire

(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general

(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere

(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene

div.l: (base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf

(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye

(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle

(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere

(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas

(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is

div.l: (base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun

(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond

(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne

(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free

(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature

(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee

div.l: (base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren

(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde

(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore

(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge

(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare

(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne

(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue

div.l: (base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde

(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede

(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne

(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge

(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles

(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde

(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght

(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille

div.l: (base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue

(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit tercia pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitʳ pars quarta ~
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day

(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Wilow / elme / plane hasil and whipultre
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) Mapil thorn / bech / aspe / box chesteyn lynd / laurer
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
(base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were

div.l: (base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
¶ HHeere eendith the knyght . And heere bygynneth the prolog of the Millere
WHan that the knyght had thus his tale tolde
In al the company nas ther ȝong ne olde
That he ne seide it was a noble storye
And worthi to be drawe in memorye
And namely the gentyls euerychone
Oure ost lough and swore so mote I gone
This goth a right vnbokeled is the male
Late se now who shal telle another tale
For treuly the game is wel bigonne
Now telleth ȝe sir monk if ȝe konne
Sumwhat to quyte with the knyghtis tale
The myller that for dronke was al pale
So that vnnethe vpon his hors he sat
He wolde auale neither hood ne hat
Ne abide no man for his curtesie
But in pilatis voice he bigan to crie
And swore by armes ⁊and blood and boones
I can a noble tale for the nones . ¶
With which I wole now quyte the knygtis tale
Oure ooste saw that he was dronke of ale
And seide abide Robyn leue brother
Some better man shal telle vs first another
Abide and lete vs wirke thriftily
Not so quod he that wole not I
For I wil speke or elles go my weye
Oure ooste answeride seie on a deuel weye
Thou art a fool thi witt is ouercome
Now herkeneth quod the meller alle and some
But first I make a protestacioun
That I am dronke I knowe it by sowne
And therfore if I mys speke or saye
Wite it the ale of Southwerk I ȝou praye
For I wil telle a legend and a lyf
Bothe of a Carpenter and his wyf
Hou that Clerk the wrightes cappe
The Reue answeride and seide stynte thi clappe
Lete be thy lewid dronken harlotrie
It is a synne and eke a gret folie
To appeyren ony man or hym diffame
And eke to bringe wyues in sich name
Thou mayst ynow of other thingis sayne
This dronken myller spak ful soone agayne
And seide leue brother Oswald
Who hath no wyf is no Cokwald
But I seie not therfore that thou art one
Ther ben ful goode wyues many one
Why art thou angry with my tale now
I haue a wyf seide he as wel thou
Ȝit nold I for the oxen in my plough
Take vpon me more than Inogh
As demen of my silf that I were oon
I wole bileue that I am noon
An husbond shal not be Inquysitif
Of goddis priuite ne of his wijf . ¶
So he may fynden goddes foysen there
Of the remenaunt nedith not enquere
What shulde I more seie but the myllere
He nold his wordes for no man forbere
But tolde his Cherles tale in his manere
Me forthenkith that I shal reherce it heere
And therfore eueri gentil wight I pray
Demeth not for goddis loue that I saye
Of yuel entent but for I mote reherce
Her tales alle be thei bettir or werse
Or elles false some of my matere
And therfore who so list it not here
Turne ouer the leef and chese another tale
For ȝe shulde fynde ynow grete and smale
Of historial thing that touchith gentylnes
And eke moralite and holynes
Blame not me if that ȝe chese amys
The meller is a cherle ȝe knowe wel this
So was the Reue eke and othere moo
And harlotrie thei tolde bothe two .
Auyse ȝou and putte me out of blame
And eke men shal not maken ernest of game
¶ Heere eendith the ꝓprolog And bigynneth the tale.
WHylom ther was dwelling in Oxenford
A Riche gnoff that gestes helde to borde
And of his craft he was a Carpenter
With hym ther was dwelling a pouere scoler
Had lerned art but al his fantasie
Was turned forto lere Astrologie
And coude a certeyn of conclusiouns
To demen by Interrogaciouns
If that men axed hym in certeyn houres
Whan that men shulde haue droght or shoures
Or if men axid hym what shulde bifalle
Of eueri thing I may not riken alle
This clerk was clepid hende Nicholas
Of derne loue he couthe and pryuy solas .
And therto he was slie and ful pryue
And lyk to a mayde meke forto see
A chambre hadde he in that hostelerie
Aloone withoute ony companye
Ful fetisly dight with erbis swote .
And he hymsilf as sote as is the rote
Of licoris or of ony situale
His almagist and bokes gret and smale
His asterlabre longing for his art
His augrym stones layn ful faire apart
On shelues couchid at his beddis heed
His presse couered with a falding reed
And al aboue ther lay a gay sautrie
On which he made on nyght melodie
So swetely that al the chaumbre rong
And angelus ad virgynem he song
And aftir that he song the kingis note
Ful ofte blissed was his merie throte
And thus the swete clerk his tyme spent
Aftir his freendes fyndyng and his rent
This carpenter hadde weddid newe a wyf
Which that he loued more than his lyf
Of .Xviij. ȝere she was of age
Ielous he was and kept hir streite in cage
For she was wild and ȝong and he was olde
And demed hym silf to be lyk a cokewolde
He knew not Catoun for his witt was rude
That bade men shulde wedde his similitude
Men shulde wedde aftir her estate
For ȝouth and elde is ofte atte debate
But sith he was fallen in the snare
He most enduren as other folk his care
Faire was this ȝong wyf and therwith alle
As ony wesel hir body gent and smalle
A seynt she werid barred al of silk
A barme cloth as white as morne mylk . ¶
Vpon hir leendis ful of many a gore
White was hir smok and enbroyded al bifore
And eke byhynde on hir coler aboute
Of coleblak silk silk within and eke without
The tapes of hir white volipere
Were of the same sute of hir colere
Hir filet brode of silk and sett ful hye
And sikerly she had a likerouse ye
Ful smale pulled was hir browes two
And tho were bent and blak as ony slo
She was ful more blisful forto see
Then is the newe perient tre
And softer than the wolle is of awther
And by hir girdil hyng a purs of leder
Tassid wᵗith silk et perlid with latoun
In alle this world to seke up and doun
Ther nys no man so wys that couthe thenke
So gay poplote or wenche
Ful bright was the shynyng of hir hewe
Than in the toure ful noble forgid newe
But of hir song it was as loude and ȝerne
As ony swalo sittyng on a berne
Therto she couth skippe and make a game
As ony kide or calf folowinge his dame
Hir mouth was swete as bragot or the methe
Or hord of apples leyd in hey or heth
Wynsyng she was and as a Ioly colt
Long as a mast and vpward as a bolt
A broche she bare on hir loue colere
As brode as is the boos of a bokelere
Hir shoos were lased on hir legges hye
She was a prymrol a pigges nye
For ony lord to liggen in his bedde
Or ȝit for ony ȝoman to wedde
Now sir and efte sir and so bifelle the caas
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Fel with this ȝong wyf forto rage and play
Whyle that hir husbonde was at Osenay
As clerkes ben ful subtel and ful queynte
And pryuyly he cauȝt hir bi the queynte
And seide thus but I haue my wille
For derne loue of thee lemman I spille
And helde hir fast by the haunche bones
And seide lemman wel at ones
Or I wole dye so god me saue
And she sprong as a colt in traue
And with hir heed she wreied fast aweye
She seide I wille not kisse thee by my fey
Whi labbe qd she late be Nicholas
Or I wole crie out harrow and allas
Do way ȝoure hondis for ȝoure curtesye
This Nicholas gan mercy forto crie
And spak so faire and profride hym ful fast
That she hir loue grauntide hym atte last
And swere hir outh by seynt thomas of kent
That she wolde ben at his comaundement
Whanne that she may hir leyser wel aspie
Myn husbonde is so ful of Ielousye
That but ȝe wayte wel and ben pryuye
I wote right wel I nam but deed qd she
Ȝe mote ben ful derne as in this caas
Nay therof care ȝou nought ꝙquod Nicholas .
A clerk hadde litherly bisett his while
But if he coude a carpenter bigyle
And thus they acorded and sworne
To awayte a tyme as I haue seid biforne
Whanne Nicholas hadde don thus euery del
And thakkid hir aboute the leendes wel
He kissith hir swete and takith his sautrie
And plaieth fast and maketh melodye
Thanne fel it thus that to the parish chirche
Cristes owne werkis to wirche
This gode wyf vpon a halyday
Hir forheed shoon as bright as ony day
So was it wash whanne she lete hir werke
Now was ther of the chirche a parishe clerke
The which that was clepid absalon
Crue was his heed as the gold it shoon
And stroutide as a fanne large and brode
Ful streiȝt and euene lay his Ioly shoode
His rood was reed his yȝen grey as goos
With powles wyndowes coruen in his shoos
In hosen reed he wente fetisly
Cladde he was ful smal and ꝓpropurly
Al in a kirtil of light waget
Ful faire and thikke ben the poyntis sett
And therupon he hadde a gay surplice
As whyte as is the blossum on the rice
A merye child he was so god me saue
Wel couthe he lete blode clippe and shaue
And make a chartre of lond or A quytaunce
In twenty maner couthe he trippe and daunce
Aftir the scole of oxenford thoo
And with his legges casten to and fro
And playn songes on a smale ribibe
Somtyme he song a loude quynyble
And as wel coude he pleye on a giterne
In al the town nas brewhous ne tauerne
That he ne viset with his solas
Ther ony gaylard tapster was
But soth to seyn he was somdel squaymous
Of fartyng and of speche daungerous
This absolon that was Ioly and gay
Goth with a sensere on the sonday
Sensynge the wyfes of the parishe faste
And many a louely loke on hem he caste
And namely on the carpenteres wyf
To loke on hir hym thought a mery lyf .
She was so propre and swete and likerous
I dar wel seie and she hadde be a mous
And he a catte he wolde hir hente anoon
This parish Clerk this Ioly absolon
Hath in his herte sich a loue longing
That of no wyf toke he noon offryng
For curtesie he seide he wolde noon
The mone whanne it was nyȝt bright shoon
And absolon his giterne hath take
For ꝑper/paramours he thought forto wake
And forth he goth Ielous and amerous
Til he come to the carpenteres hous
A litel aftir the kok hadde crowe
And dresside hym vndir a shet wyndowe
That was vpon the Carpenters walle
He singith in his voice gentyl and smal
Now dere lady if thi wille be
I preie ȝou that ȝe wil rew on me
Ful wel acording to his giternyng
This carpenter awoke and herde hym sing
And spak vnto his wyf and seide anoon
What Alisoun herest thou not absolon
That chaunteth thus vndir oure boures wal
And she answeride hir husbonde therwith al
Ȝis god wote Iohn I here it euery del
This passith forth what wole ȝe thanne but wel
Fro day to day this Ioly absolon
So wowith hir that hym was wo bigon
He wakith al the nyght and al the day
He kymbes his lokkes brode and made hem gay
He wowith hir by menes and brocage
And swore he wolde be hir owne page
He singith brokkyng as a nyghtyngale
He sent hir pyment meth and spiced ale
And wafres piping hote out of the glede
And for she of toun he profride meede ¶
For some folk wole be wonnen for richesse
And some for strokis and some for gentylnesse
Somtyme to shewe his lightnes and maistrie
He plaieth herowdes vpon a scaffold high
But what auaileth hym as in this caas
So loueth she this hende Nicholas
That absolon may blowe the bukhorne
He ne hadde for his labour but a scorne
And thus she makith absolon hir ape
Al his ernest turneth but to a Iape
For soth this ꝓprouerbe it is no lie
Men seyn thus al weye the nygh slye
Makith the fer loue to be loth
For though that absolon be wode or wroth
By cause that he fer was from hir sight
This nygh Nicholas stood in his light
Now bere ȝe wel hende Nicholas
For absolon may weyle and singe alas
And so bifel it on a satirday
This carpenter was gon to Osenay
And hende nycholas and alisoun
Acordid were to this conclusioun
That nycholas shal shapen hym a wile
This sely Ielous husbonde to bigyle
And if so be the game wente a right
She shulde slepe in his arme al nyght
For this was his desire and hir also
And right anoon withoute wordis mo
This Nicholas no lenger wole tarie
But doth ful softe vnto his chaumbre carie
Bothe mete and drynke for a day or twey
And to hir husbonde bad hir forto seye
If that he axid aftir Nicholas
She shulde sey she nyst where he was
Of al that day she saw hym not with ye
She trowide that he was in maladie
For no crye hij may coude calle
He nold answere for nought that myght bifalle
This passeth forth al the satirday
That Nicholas stille in his bed lay
And eet and sleep and what hym list
Til sonnenday that the sonne goth to rest
This sely carpentere hath gret meruayle
Of Nicholas or what thing myght hym ayle
And seide I am a drad bi seynt Thomas
It stondith not a right with Nicholas
God shild that he diede sodeynly
This world is now ful tikul sikirly
I saw to day a corps bore to chirche
That now on monday last I saw hym wirche
Go vp qd he to his knaue anoon
Clepe at his dore or knak with a stoon
Loke hou it is and telle me boldly
This knaue went hym up ful sturdyly
And at chaumbre dore while that he stode
He cried and knocked as he were wode
What how what do ȝe maystir Nicholay
How may ȝe slepe al the long day
But alle for nought he herde neuer a word
Vndir a bed ful lowe he fond a borde
Ther as the Cat was wont to crepe
And at the hole he lokide In ful depe
And atte last he hadde of hym a sight
This Nicholas sat euere gaping upright
As he hadde kiked in the new mone
A doun he goth and told his maist̉er/re soone
In what array he saw this ilk man
This Carpenter to blissen hym bigan
And seide helpe us seynt frideswide
A man wote litel what shal hym bitide
This man is fallen with his Astronomye
In some woodnes or in some Agonye ¶
I thought wel hou it shulde be
Men shulde not knowe of goddis pryuyte
Ȝhe blessid be al wey the lewid man
That not but oonly his bileue can
So ferd another clerk with astronomye
He walkide in the feeldis forto prye
Vpon the sterres to wite what shulde byfalle
Til he was in a marle pitt falle
He saw not but ȝit by seynt thomas
Me rewith sore hynde Nicholas
He shal be rated of his studiyng
If that I may bi ihıı̄uns heuene king
Gete me a staff þat I may vndirspore
While that thou Robyn heuest vp the dore
He shal out of his studiyng as I gesse
And to the chaumbre dore he gan hym dresse
His knaue was a strong carle for the nones
And bi the haspe he haf it up at oones
In the flore the dore fel anoon
This Nicholas sat ay stil as stoon
And euere gapid vpward into the eire
This carpenter wende he were in dispeire
And hent hym by the shuldris myghtilie
And shook hym hard and cried spitouslie
What Nicholay what loke adoun
Awake and thenke on cristis passioun
I couche thee from yuels and fro wightes
Therwith ȝe myght spel he seide anoon rightes
On foure halfes of the hous aboute
And on the threshfold on the dore withoute
Ihu crist and seynt Benedight
Blisse this hous from euery wickid wight
For the nyghtes verye the white pater noster
Where wentist thou seynt petris suster
And atte laste this heende nycholas
Gan forto sike sore and seide allas .
Shal al the world be lost eftesones now
The Carpentere answeride what seistow
What think on god as we don men that swink
This Nicholas answeride fecche me drink
And aftir wil I speke in pryuyte
Of certeyn thing that touchith thee and me
I wil telle it noon other man certeyn
This carpentere goth doun and cometh ageyn
And brought of myghty ale a large quart
And whanne that ech of hem hadde dronk his part
This Nicholas his dore fast shette
And doun the carpentere by hym he sette
And seide Iohn myn oost leef and dere
Thou shalt upon thi trouthe swere me heere
That to no wight thou shalt this counsel wreye
For it is cristes counseill that I seye
And if thou telle it man thou art forlore
For this vengeaunce thou shalt haue therfore
That if thou wreye me thou shalt be wood
Nay crist forbede it for his hooly blood
Qd tho this sely man I nam no labbe
Ne though I sey I am not leef to gabbe
Seie what thou wilt I shal it neuer telle
To child ne wyf by hym that harowid helle
Now Iohn qd Nicholas I wil not lie
I haue founde in myn Astrologie
I haue loked in the moone bright
That now a monday next at quarter nyght
Shal falle a reyn and that so wylde and wood
That half so gret was neuere Nowels flood
This world he seide in lesse than in an hour
Shal al be dreynt so hidous is the shour
Thus shal mankynde drenche and lese her lyf
This carpentere answeride allas my wyf
And shal she drenche allas myn Alisoun
For sorowe of this he fel al most a doun . ¶
And seide is no remedie in this cas
Whi ȝis for god qd hynde Nicholas
If thou worche aftir my lore and rede
Thou mayst not wirken after thyn owne hede
For thus seith Salamon that was ful trewe
Worche al bi counseil and thou shalt nought rewe
And if thou werken wolt bi good counseill
I vndirtake withoute mast or seill
Ȝit shal I saue hir and thee and me
Hastow nought herd hou saued was Noe
Whanne that oure lord hath warned hym biforn
That al the world with watir shulde be lorn
Ȝis qd this carpentere ful ȝore a go
Hastow not herd qd Nicholas also
The sorowe of Noe with his felowshipp
Er that he myght gete his wyf to shipp
Hym hadde leuer I dar wel vndirtake
At thilk tyme than alle his wethers blake
That she hadde a shipp hir silf aloone
And therfore wostow what is best to don
This axith haste and of an hastyf thing
Men may nought preche or make tariyng
Anoon go gete us fast into this ynne
A knedyng trough or ellis a kemelyne
For ech of us but loke that thei ben large
In whiche men mowen swymme as in a barge
And han ther vitailes suffisaunt
But for a day fy on the remenaunt
The watir shal aslake and gon away
Aboute pryme vppon the next day
But Robyn may nought wite of this thi knaue
Ne ekꝭes the mayde gylle I may nouȝt saue
Axe nought whi for though thou axe me
I wole nought telle goddis pryuyte
Suffisith thee but if thi wittes madde
To haue as gret a grace as Noe hadde
Thy wyf shal I saue oute of dowte
Go now thi weye and spede thee here aboute
But whanne thou hast for hir and þee and me
Geten vs these kneding tubbes three
Thanne shalt thou hange hem in the roof ful high
That no man of oure puruyaunce aspie
And whanne thou thus hast don as I haue seid
And hast oure vitail faire in hem leid
And ekꝭes an axe to smyte the corde a two
Whanne that the watir cometh that we may go
And breke an hole on high vpon the gable
Vnto the gardeyn ward ouer the stable
That we may frely passen forth oure wey
Whanne that the gret shoure is gon awey
Thanne shalt thou swymme as mery I vndirtake
As doth the white dogge aftir the drake
Thanne wil I clepe how alisoun how Iohn
Be mery for the flood wole passe anoon
And thou wolt seye hayl mayster Nicholay
Gode morne I see the wel for it is day
And thanne shal we be lordis al oure lyf
Of al the world as Noe and his wyf
But that of o thing I warne thee ful right
Be wel auysed on that ylk nyght
That we ben entrid into the shippes borde
That noon of us ne speke not a word
Ne clepe ne crye but ben in his praiere
For it is goddis owne heeste dere
Thi wyf and thou mot hange fer a twynne
For that bitwixe ȝou shal be no synne
No more in loking than ther shal in dede
This ordinaunce is seid god the spede
To morowe at nyght whanne men ben alle on slepe
Into oure kneding tubbes wil we crepe
And sitten there abidinge goddis grace
Go now thi weye I haue no lenger space ¶
To make of this no lenger sermonyng
Men seyn thus . sende the wise and seie nothing .
Thou art so wys nedith thee not teche
Go saue oure lyues and that I thee biseche
This sely Carpentere goth forth his weye
Ful ofte he seide allas and welaweye
And to his wyf he tolde his pryuyte
And she was warre and knewe it bet than he
What al this queynte cast was forto seye
But netheles she ferde as she wolde deye
And seide allas go forth thi weie anoon
Helpe us to scape or we ben deed echon
I am thi trewe verray weddid wyf
Go dere spouse and helpe to saue oure lyf
Lo which a gret thing is affeccioun
Men may die of ymagynacioun
So depe may impressioun be take
This sely carpentere bigynnith quake
Him thenkith verrayly that he may se
Noe flood come walkinge as the see
To drenchen Alisoun his hony dere
He wepith weylith makith sory chere
He sikith with ful many a sory sough
And goth and getith hym a kneding trough
And aftir a Tubbe and a kemelyn
And pryuyly he sent hem to his In
And henge hem in the roof in pryuyte
His owne hond he made ekꝭes leddrea thre
To clymben by the ronges and the stalkes
Vnto the tubbes hanginge in the balkes
And hem vitayled bothe trouh and tubbe
With brede and with chese and with good ale in a Iubbe
Suffising right inow as for a day
But er þᵗat he hadde maad al this array
He sent his knaue and ekꝭes his wenche also
Vppon his nede to london forto go
And on the monday whanne it drough to nyght
He shitte his dore withoute candel light
And dressid al thing as it shulde be
And shortly clumben up al thre
Thei setten stille wel a furlong way
Now pater nost̉er/re . Clum seide Nicholay
And Clum qd Iohn and clum seide Alisoun
This Carpentere seide his deuocioun
And stille he sitte and biddith his preiere
Awayting on the rayn if he it here
The deth slepe for wery bisynesse
Fel on this Carpentere right as I gesse .
Aboute Corfew tyme or litel more
For trauel of his goost he groneth sore
And efte he rowtith for his heed myslay
Doun of the ladder stalkith Nicholay
And Alisoıı̄un ful softe adoıı̄un she spedde
Withouten wordis mo thei gon to bedde
There as the Carpenter is wont to lye
Ther was the reuel and the melodie
And thus lyth alisoun and nycholas
In bisynesse or myrthe and of solas .
Til that the belle of laudis bigan to rynge
And freris in the Chauncell gonne synge
This parish Clerk this amorous Absolon
That is for loue alwey so wo bigon
Vpon the monday was at Osenay
With company hym to desporte and play .
And axide vppon cas A cloisterere
Ful pⁱriuyly aftir Iohn the Carpentere
And he drowȝ hym a part out of the chirche
And seide I note I saw hym hrere not worche
Sith satirday I trowe that he be went
For tymber there oure abbot hath hym sent
For he is wont for tymber for to go
And dwellen atte graıı̄unge a day or two . ¶
Or ellis he is at his hous certeyn
Where that he be I can nought sothly seyn .
This Absolon ful ioly was and lyght
And thought now is tyme to wake al nyght
For sikirly I saw hym nought stiryng
Aboute his dore sith day bigan to spryng
So mote I thryue I shal at Cokkis crowe
Ful pⁱriuyly knocke at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe vppon his bowres walle
To Alisoun now wole I tellen alle
My loue longing for ȝit I shal not misse
That atte leest weye I shal hir kisse .
Som mane comfort shal I haue parfay
My mouth hath icched al this long day
That is a signe of kissing atte leeste
Al nyght me met ekꝭes I was at a feeste
Therfor I wole go slepe an our or tweye
And al the nyght thanne wil I wake and pleye
Whanne that the firste cok hath crowe anoon
Vp rist þis ioly louer Absolon
And hym arayeth gay and poynt deuise
But first he chewith greyn and likorise
To smellen soote er he hadde kempt his here
Vndir his tunge a trewe loue he bere
For therby wende he to be gracious
And rometh to the Carpenters hous .
And stille he stant vndir the shot wyndowe
Vnto his brest it raught it was so lowe
And softe he coughed with a semey soun
What do ȝe hony combe swete Alisoun
My faire brid my swete synamome
Awaketh lemman myn and spekith to me
Wel litel thenken ȝe vppon my wo
That for ȝoure loue I swete ar I go
No wondir is though that I swelt and swete
I morne as doth the lambe aftir the tete
I wys lemman I haue sich loue longing
That ilkꝭes a turtel trewe is my mornyng
I may not eten no more than a mayde
Go fro the wyndow Iak fool he seide
As helpe me god it wil nought be compame
I loue another and ellis I were to blame
Wel bette than thee she seide Absolon
Go forth thi wey or I wil cast astoon
And lete me slepe a twenty deuel wey
Allas qd Absolon and welawey
That trewe loue was euere so yuel bisett
Than kisse me syn it may be no bett
For ihus loue and for the loue of me
Wolt thou thanne go thi weye therwith seide she
Ȝhe certis lemman qd this Absolon
Thanne make thee redy qd she I come Anon
This Absolon doun sette hym on his knees
And seide I am a lord atte alle degrees
For aftir this I hope ther cometh more
Lemman thi grace and swete brid thin ore
The wyndow she vndoth and that in hast
Haue do qd she come off and spede thee fast
Lest that oure neighbores thee aspye
This Absolon gan wipe his mouth ful drye
Derk was the nyght as picche or as the cole
And at the wyndow out she putte hir hole
And Absolon hym fel no bette ne wers
But with his mouth he kiste hir naked ers
Fulⁱ sauourly er he was war of this
A bak a stert and thought amys
For wel he wist a womman hath no berd
He felt a thing al rough and long hered
And seide fy allas what haue I do
Tehe qd she and clapt the wyndow to
And Absolon goth forth a sory paas
A berde a berde seide hynde Nicholas . ¶
What wole ȝe more but this goth faire and wel
This sely Absolon herde it euerydel
And on his lippe he gan for angre bite
And to hym silf he seide I shal thee quite
Who rubbith now who frotith now his lippes
With dust with sonde with straw with cloth with chippes
But Absolon that seith ful ofte Allas
My soule bitake y to sathanas
But me were leuer than al this toun qd he
Of this dispite Awroken forto be
Allas qd he allas I ne hadde bleynt
His hote loue is cold and al queynt
For fro that tyme that he hadde kist hir ers
Of ꝑper/paramours he sette not a kers
For he was helid of his maladye
Ful ofte ꝓproamours he gan diffie
And wepe as doth a child that is bete
A softe paas he wente ouer the strete
Vnto a smyth men clepen hym daun Geruays
That in his forge smythieth plough harnays
He sharpith sharre and culter bisily
This Absolon knokkith al esyly
And seide vnto Gerueys and that anoon
What who art thou . It is am I Absolon
What Absolon what Cristes swete tree
Why rise ȝe so rathe ey benedicite
What eylith ȝow Som gay gerle god it woot
Hath brought ȝow thus on the viritot
By Seynt note ȝe wote wel what I mene
This Absolon ne roughte not a bene
Of al his pley no word ageyn he gaf
He hadde more tow on his distaf
Than Gerueys knewe and seide freend so dere
The hote Culter in the chymeney heere
As lene it me I haue therwith to done
I wole bringe it ageyn ful soone
Gerueys answeride certis were it gold
Or in a poke nobles vntold
Thou shuldist haue as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes foo what wil ȝe do therwith
Therof qd Absolon be as be may
I shal wel tellen it thee to morowe day
And caught the culter by the cold stele
Ful softe oute at the dore he gan stele
And wente vnto the carpentere wal
He koughede first and knokked therwithal
Vpon the wyndow right as he dide ere
This Alisoun answeride who is there
That knockith so I warant it a theef
Why nay qd he god wote my swete leef
I am thin Absolon thin derlyng
Of gold qd he I haue thee brought a ryng .
Mi modir ȝaf it me so god me saue
Ful fyn it is and therto wel graue
This wil I ȝeue thee if thou me kisse
This Nicholas was risen forto pisse
And thought he wolde amenden al the Iape
He shulde kisse his ers er that he scape
And up the wyndow dide he hastily
And oute his ers he putte pryuyly
Ouer the buttok to the haunche bon
And therwith spak this clerk this absolon
Speke swete brid I nat where thou art
This Nicholas a noon leet fligh a fart
As gret as it hadde ben a thonder dent
That with the stroke he was almost blent
And he was redy with his yrene hote
And Nicholas in the ers he smote
Of goth the skyn an handebrede aboute
The hote culter brenned so his toute
And for the smert he wende forto dye
As he were wood for woo he gan to crye ¶
Help water water help for lo I smerte
This carpenter oute of his slombre sterte
And herde oon crien watir as he were wood
And seide allas now cometh nowelis flood
And sette him vp withoute wordis mo
And with an Ax he smote the corde a two
And doun goth al he fonde neithir to selle
No bred nor ale til he come to the selle
Vpon the floor and there aswowen he lay
Vp stirte hir Alisoıı̄un and Nicholay
And criede oute and harrow in the strete
The neighbores bothe smale and grete
In ronnen forto gauren on this man
That a swown lay bothe pale and wan
For with that fal he brusten hath his arme
But stonden he must vnto his owne harme
For whanne he spak he was anoon bore doun
With hynde Nicholas and Alisoun
Thei tolde eủer/rey man that he was wood
He was a gast so of the Nowels flood
Thurgh fantasie that of his vanyte
He hadde bought hym kneding tubbes three
And hadde hem hanged in the roof aboue
And that he praiede hem for goddis loue
To sitten in the roof ꝑper/par companye
The folk gan laughwen at his fantasie
And to the roof thei kiken and thei gape
And turned al his harm vnto a Iape
For what this carpentere answerde
It was for nought no man his resoıı̄un herde
With othes gret he was sworne adoun
That he was holden wood in al that toun
For euery clerk anoon right helde with other
Thei seide the man is wood my leue brother
And eủer/rey wight gan laughwen at his stryf
Thus swyued was the carpenters wyf .
For al his kepyng and his Ialousie
And Absolon hath kist hir nether ye
And Nicholas is scaldid in his toute
This tale is don and god saue al the route

¶Heere eendith the ꝓprolog
and bigynneth the tale
(base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
(base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke

div.l: (base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
(base) As piled as an Ape was his skulle
(base) He was a Market beter at the fulle
(base) Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
(base) That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
(base) A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
(base) And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
(base) His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
(base) A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
(base) The person of the toun hir fader was
(base) With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
(base) For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
(base) She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
(base) For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
(base) But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
(base) To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
(base) And she was proud and peert as is a pye
(base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
(base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
