Nowe felle yt so þat fortune leste no lenger /
The hyȝe pryde of Nero to cherise
For þouȝe he were stronge ȝit was she strenger
Sche þouȝt þus be god I am to nyce
To sette a man þat ys fulfyllid of vice
In hiȝe degre and Emꝑper/parour hym calle
Be god oute of his sete I wille hym trice
Whan he beste wenteth sonnest shalle he falle
The peple roos vpon hym on a nyȝt
For hyd defaute and whan he it asspyed
Oute of hys dores a none he hath hy dyȝt
Anone and there he wende hade bene alyed
He knocked faste and ay þe more he cryed
Þe faster shetten þei þe dores alle
Þoo wyste he wele he hade hym selfe mys gyede
And wente his way no lenger wolde he calle
The peple cryed and rombled vp ⁊and doun
Þat with hys Eeres harde þei howe he sayde
Where ys þis fals traytoᵘur þis Neron
For fere almoste oute of his witte he brayde
And to hys goddes pitously he sayd
For socoure but it myȝt / not be tyde
For drede of þis hym þouȝte þat he dyed
And ran in to a Gardyn hym selfe to hyde
¶ And in þis Gardeyne fonde he Cherles tweye
Þat seten by a fyre fulle grete ⁊and rede
And to þese Clerkes twey he gan to preye
To slene hym and to gerden of his heede
Þat to his body whan þat he were dede
Were no dyspyte y doo for hys defame
Hym selfe he slowe he coude no bett̉er/ree rede
Of whiche fortune louh ⁊and made a game
Was neuere A captayne vnder a kynge
Þat regnes moo put in subieccioun
Ne strenger was in þe felde of alle thynge
And in his tyme ne gretour of renoun
Ne more pompous in hiȝe psumpcioun
Than Olyferne whiche fortune ay keste
So lycrousely and ladde hym vp ⁊and doun
Tyl þat hys heed was off or þat he wyste
Not only þat þis worlde hade hym aw
For lesynge of Richesse ⁊and of lyberte
But he made euery man rennew hys lawe
Nabigodonosor was lord said he
None oþere god shulde honoured be
A yenest his heste no wyȝt dar trespace
Saue in betulia a stronge Cite
Where Elyachym a preste was of þat place
But take kepe of þe deþe of Oleferne
A mydde hys hoste he dronke lay a nyȝt
With Inne his tent large as in a berne
And ȝit for alle hys pompe and alle hys myȝt
Iudith a woman as he lay vp ryȝt
Slepynge hys hede of smote ⁊and fro his tent
Fulle pryuely she stale fro euery wyȝt
What nedethe it of kynge Anteocheus
To telle hys hiȝe ⁊and ryal Maieste
Hys hyeȝ pryde hys werke venemous
For suche an oþer was neuere none but he
Redeth whiche he wa in makabe
And redeth þe proude wordes þat he sayde
And why he felle fro hys prosperite
And in an hylle howe wrecchidly he didde
Fortune hym hade enhaunced so in pryde
Þat verraly he wende he myȝt enteyne
Vnto þe sterres vpon euery syde
And in a Balaunce to weye þe Mountayne
And alle þe floodes on þe see restreyne
And goddes peple hade he moste in hate
Hem wolde he slee in torment ⁊and in peyne
Wenynge þat god ne myȝt / hys pryde Abate
And for þat Nychamour and Gymothe
With Iewes were venquesshed myȝtly
Vnto þe Iewes suche an hade hade he
Þat he hade greued hys chare full hastely
And swore and sayde fulle spitousely
Vnto Ierlin wolde he efte sone
To wreke his Ire on hit fulle cruelly
But of his purpos he was lette fulle sone
God of hys manace hym so sore smote
Wiþe Invisyble woundes ay vn curable
Þat in hys guttes carf so a boute
Þat hys peynes were inportable
And certeynly þe wreche was resonable
For many mannes guttes did he peyne
But fro hys purpos cursyd and dampnable
For alle hys smerte he nolde hym restreyne
But bade anone apparayle his hoost
And sodeynly or he was of hit ware
God dauntyd alle his pryde and all his boost
For he so sore felle oute of hys care
Þat hurte his lymes ⁊and his skyn to tare
So þat he ne myȝt goo no ryde
But in a chayre men aboute hy bare
Alle for brused bothe backe ⁊and syde
The wrecche of god hym smote so cruelly
Þat in hys body wycked wormes crepe
And þere with alle he stonke so horribly
Þat none of alle hys meyne þat hym kepte
Wheþere þat he wooke or elles slepe
Ne myȝt not þe stynke of hym endure
In þis myschef he wayled and eke wepte
And knew god his lorde to fore eny creature
To alle hys hoost and to hym self also
Full fulsom was þe stynk of hys careyne
No man myȝt hym bere to ⁊and fro
And in his stynk and hys horrible peyne
He starfe fulle wrecchedly in a Mounteyne
Þus hathe þis robboure and homycide
Þat many a man made to wepe ⁊and pleyne
Suche guerdon as bilongeth vnto pryde
The storye of Alysaundre ys so comune
Þat euery wyȝt þat hath discrecioun
Hath herde some what or alle of hys fortune
Þis wyde worlde as in conclusioıı̄un
He wan be strenȝte and for hys hyȝe rennoun
They were gladde for pees vnto hym sende
Þe pryde of man ⁊and beste þe leyde a doun
Where so he came vnto þe worldes ende
Comparysoun myȝt nevere be maked
Be twene hym and a noþere Conquerour
For alle þis worlde for drede of hym hath quaked
He was of knyȝthode and of fredom floure
Fortune hym made þe heyre of hir honoure
Saue wyn and wemen no thenge myȝt / aswage
Hys hyȝe entent in armes and laboure
So was he fulle of lovynge corage
What pite were it to hym þouȝe I you tolde
Of darious and an hundred þousand moo
Of kynges prynces and Erles bolde
Whiche he conquered and brouȝt hym in to woo
I saye as ferre as man may ryde or go
Þe worlde was hys what shulde I more devise
For þouȝe I wryte I and tolde you euere moo
Of hys knyȝthode hit myȝt not suffice
Twelue ȝeere he regned as saith machabe
Philippes son of Masydone was he
Þat first was kynge of grece þe Contre
O worthy gentil Alysaunder Alas qd he
Þat euer shulde falle in suche degre
Empoysened of þi folke þou were
Þi fortune in to an Aasse hathe turned the
And ȝet for þe ne wepe she nevere a teere
Lloo shal yeue teeres men to compleyne
Þe deþe of gentilnesse and of Fraunchise
Þat alle þe worlde welde in hys demeyne
And ȝet hym þouȝte he myȝt not suffice
So fulle was his corage of hiȝe empryse
Alas who shal me helpe to endyte
False fortune and poyson to dispise
The whiche too of alle þis woo I wyte
By wysdom manhode ⁊and by laboure
Fro humbleheed and fro ryalle maieste
Vp roos Iulyus þe noble conquerour
Þat alle þe Occident by londe ⁊and by see
By strenght of honde or elles by trete
And vnto Roome made hem tⁱbutarye
And siþens of Rome þe Emporour was he
Tyl þat fortune wexe hys Aduersarye
O myȝti Cesar þat in Tesalye
A yenest pompeous fader þine in lawe
Þat of þe Oriente hade alle þe Chyualrie
As ferre as þe day begynnethe to dawe
Þorouȝe þi knyȝthode haste hym take ⁊and slowe
Saue a fewe folke þat wᵗith pompius fledde
For þe whiche þou puttest alle þe Orient in Awe
Thonke fortune þat þ wele spedde
But nowe I lytelle while I wille be wayle
Thys pompeous þis noble governoure
Of Rome whiche þat fleye at þis batayle
I say oon of his men a false traytour
Hys hede of smote to wynne hym fauoure
Of Iulius and hym þe heede brouȝt
Alas pompeous of þe Orient conquerour
Þat fortune vnto suche a fyne brouȝt
To Rome a yeyne repeyreth Iulius
With hys tryvmphe laureate fulle hyȝe
But on atyme Brutus Casseus
Þat euere hade of hys estate Envye
Fulle pryvely hade made conspiracie
Ayeinste þis Iulyus in subtile wyse
And caste þe place on whiche he shulde dye
Wiþe boydekyns as I shalle you devise
Thys Iulyus to þe Capitoyle went
Vpon a day as he was wonte to gone
And in þe Capitoile anone hym hent
Þis fals brutus and hys fals foon
Hathe styked hym with boydkyns anoon
With many a wounde and þus þei lete hym lye
But nevere gronte he at no stroke but oon
Or elles at too but ȝif hys storye lye
To manly was þis Iulyus of hert
And so wele loued estatly honeste
Þat þouȝe hys dedely woundes so sore smert
Hys mantelle ouere hys hepes caste he
For no man shulde see hys pryvete
And as he lay in deynge on a traunce
And wyste verrayly þat dede was he
Of honeste ȝit hade he remembraunce
Lucane to þis storie I remembre
And to sweton and to valeryus also
Þat of þis storye wryteth worde ⁊and ende
How þat þere grete conquerours two
Fortune was hir frende and aftyr hir foo
No man truste vpon hys favoure longe
But / haue here in a wayte euere moo
Wytnesse of alle þese conquerours stronge
Thys ryche Gresus whilom kynge of lyde
Of whiche Gresus Sequius sore hy dradde
Ȝit was he cauȝte amonge alle þis pryde
And to be brent men to þe fuyre hym ladde
But suche arayn doun fro þe walken shadde
Þat slowe þe fyre and made hym to escape
But to be ware ȝit no grace he hade
Til fortune on þe Galowes made hym gape
Whan he escaped was can he not stynte
For to begynne a newe regne a yeyne
He wende wele for þat fortune hy sent
Suche happe þat he escaped þorowe þe reyne
Þat of hys foos he myȝt not be slayne
A suche a sweuen vpon a nyȝt he mette
Of whiche he was so proude and eke fayne
Þat he in vengeaunce alle hys hert sette
Uppe on a tre he was as hym thouȝt
Þere Iubiter hym wyssh both hale ⁊and syde
And phebus eke a fayre to well hym brouȝt
To dry hym wᵗith and þerfore wexe hys pryde
And to hys douȝter þat stode hy besyde
Whiche þat he knewe in hye sentence habounde
He bade hir telle what it signefied
And she his dreme þus expounde
The tre qd she þe Galows ys to mene
And Iubiter bitokeneth snawe ⁊and rayne
And phebus wᵗith his towel so clere
Tho bene þe sonne stremys forto sayne
Þou shalte an honged be fader certayne
Rayne shalle þe wasshe and sonne shal þe drye
Þus warned she hym fulle plat ⁊and fulle playne
Hys douȝter þat callyd was phavye
An honged was Cresus þe proude kynge
His ryal trone myȝt hy not availe
Tregedys ys none oþere maner þenge
Nay can in synnynge crye ne be wayle
But þat fortune alwey wolle assayle
Wᵗith vn ware strok þe reynes þat ben proude
For whan men trusteth here þan wolle she fayle
And couere hir bryȝt face wᵗith a cloude
Here endeth þe tale of þe Monke

l.hi: ere begynneth þe proloog of þe Nıı̄unne Preoste .

div.l: HOo qd þe knyȝt gode sir no more of thys
Þat ȝe han sayde ys riȝt ynoweȝ y wys .
And mochel more for litel hevynesse
Ys ryȝt ynouȝe to mechel folk as I gesse
I sey for me hit ys a grete disese ¶Monke
Where as men han ben in grete helth ⁊and eese
To herene of her sodeyn fall Alas
And þe Contrarye is grete Ioy ⁊and solace
And whan a man hath ben in pore estate
And clymbith vp and wexeth fortunate
And þere abydeth in ꝓprosperite
Suche thynge ys . gladsom as hit thynketh me
And þouȝe suche thynge were goodely forto telle
// Ye . qd oure hoost by Seynt poules belle
Ye say riȝt sothe þis Monke clappeth loude
He . spake howe fortune coủer/reed wᵗith a cloude
I note neuere what ⁊and also of a tregide
Ryȝt nowe ye herd ⁊and ꝑper/parde no remedie
Hit ys forto be wayle ⁊and complayne .
Þat þat ys done and als hit ys a payne
As ye haue sayd to here of hevinesse
Sir Monke no more of þis so god you blesse
Your tale annoyeth al þis companye
Suche talkynge ys not worth a butter flyeȝ
And þere in ys . na sporte nor no game
Where fore Sir Monke Doun Piers by your name
I pray you hertely telle vs som what elles
For siker nere clynkynge of your belles .
Þat in your bridell hongeth on euery syde
By heuen kynge þat for vs alle dyede
I shalle for þis falle doıı̄un for slepe
Al þouȝe þe sloweȝ hade neuere be so depe
Þan hath youre tale ben tolde in vayne
For certeynly as þese clerkes sayne
Where as a man may han none audience
Nouȝt helpeth to tellen hys sentence
And wele I woote þe substaunce ys in me
Yf ony thynge shal wele reportid me be
Sir saye some what of huntynge I you praye
Nay qd þe Monke I haue no luste to playe
Now let a noþer telle as I haue tolde ¶The Nıı̄unne
Þan spake oure Oste with rude speche and bolde
And sayd vnto þe Nonnes Preost a none
Come nere Sir Preost cōmme nere sir Iohn
Telle vs suche thenges as may our hertes glade
Be mery þoıı̄unȝe þou ryde vpon a Iade
Þat þei þine hors be foule or lene
Yf he wille serve þe recke þe nouȝt a bene
Looke þat þine hert be mery euere mo .
Ȝis . hoste d he so mote I ryde or go .
But I be mery y wys I wille be blamed
And riȝt a none he hathe hys tale y tamed .
And þus he sayde to vs euereicheon
Thys swete preost þis gode man Sir Iohn
A pore wydowe some dele stope īm age
Was whilom dwellyng īm a narow cotage
Be sydes a grove stondynge in a dale
Thys wydow of whiche I telle you my tale
Syþens þilke day þat she was laste a wyfe
In pacience ladde a fulle symple lyf
For lytelle was hir catelle ⁊and hir rent
By husbondry of suche þat god hir sent
Sche fonde hir self ⁊and eke hir douȝtren two
Thre large sowes hade she ⁊and no moo /
Thre kyne ⁊and eke a shepe þat hiȝt / mal
Ful soty was hir boure and eke hir hall .
In whiche she ete many a sclender mele
Of poynaunte sawce hir nedeth never a dele
No deynte Morsell passed hir throote
Hir diete was accordaunt to hir coote
Repleciōm ne made hir neuere seke
A tempre dyete was alle hir physike
And excercise ⁊and hert sufficiaunce
Þe gowte let hir nothynge to daunce
Ne poplexie ne shente nouȝt hir heede
Ne wyne dronke she neiþer whyte nor reede ¶Prest
Her bord was served moste with white ⁊and blake
Mylke and browne brede in whiche she fonde no lake
Seynde bakoıı̄un and some tyme an eye or tweie
For she was as hit were a manere of a deie
A gardeyne she hade enclosed alle aboute
With stykes and a drye dyche with oute
In whiche she hade a Cok þat hyȝt Chauntelere
In alle þe londe of Crawynge was hys peere
His voice was muryer þan þe murye orgon
On masse dayes þat in þe Chirche goon
Wele sykerere was þe crowynge in his logge
Then ys a Clok or an Abbey orlogge
Be nature he knewe eche ascencioun
Of equynoxiol of þilke toune
For when degrees xv were discended
Þan knewe he þat it myȝt not be amendid
Hys Combe was redder þan þe fyn Coral
And batayled as hit were a Castelle wal
Y lyke Azure were hys legges and hys toon
Hys byll was blake and as þe geet hit shone
Hys nayles whyter þan þe lily floure
And ylyke burnysshed golde was hys coloure
¶ This gentel Cok hade in hys governaunce
Seven hennes forto done his plesaunce
Whiche weren hys susters and hys ꝑper/paramours
And wonder ylyke to hym as of coloures
Of whiche þe feyrest hewet vnder þe þrote
Was clepid fayre damsell partelote
Curteys she was discrete and debonaire
And compenable and bare hir selfe so fayre
Syþens þilke day þat she was seuen nyȝt olde
Þat truly she hathe þe hert in holde
Of Chauntelere loken in euery lyth
He loved hir so þat wele was hy þere with
But suche a Ioy hit was to here hym synge
Whan þat þe bryȝt sonne gan to sprynge ¶The Nıı̄unne
In swete accord my leef is fare in londe
For þilke tyme as I haue vndirstonde
Beestes and briddes coude speke ⁊and synge
And so by felle þat in þe dawnynge
A Chauntelere amonge hys wyves alle
Sat on hys perche þat was in þe halle
And nexte hym satte þis fayre partelote
Þis Chaunteler gan gronen in his þroote
As a man þat ys in his dreme drechid sore
And whan þat partelote þus herd hym rore
Sche was agaste and said hert dere
What eylith you to grone in þis manere
Ȝe bene a verray sleper fye for shame
And he vnswared and sayd þus ma dame
I pray you þat ye take yt nouȝt agreve
Be god me mette þat I was in suche myschef
Ryȝt nowe þat ȝit myn hert ys sore a fryȝt
Nowe god qd he my sweuen rede aryȝt
And kepe my body oute of foule pⁱrisoıı̄un
Me mette þat I romed vp ⁊and doıı̄un
Within oure ȝerde where as I sauȝe a beest
Was lyke an hounde and wolde haue made a rest
Vpon my body and wolde haue hade me dede
Hys coloure was bitwexe whyte ⁊and rede
And typped was hys tayle and both hys Eeres
Wᵗith black / vnlyke þe remenaunt of his heres
Hys snowte smal wᵗith glowynge eȝen tweie
Ȝet of hys looke for fere almoste I deye
This causid me my gronynge doutelees
A voy qd she fye on you harlottys
Alas qd she for by þat god aboue
Nowe haue ye loste myn hert ⁊and myne loue
I con nouȝt loue a Coward by my faith
For certes what so eny woman seith
We alle desiren yif hit myȝt be
To han husbondes herd wise ⁊and fre ¶Prest
And secre ne no negard ne no fool
Ne hym þat ys agaste of euery tool
Ne none a vontoure by þat god above
Howe dorste ye sayne for shame vnto your loue
Þat eny thynge myȝt make you a ferde
Haue ye no mannes hert ⁊and haue a berd
Alas and kan ye be agaste of sweues
Nothynge god woote vnto shewe in sweuis
Sweuens engender of replexiounes
And ofte of synne and of complexions
Whan humours bene to habundaıı̄unt in a wyȝt
Certes þis dreme / whiche ye haue herd to nyȝt
Comyth of þe grete suꝑper/parfluite
Of youre rede coloure parde
Which causeth folke to dreme hir dremes
Of arrewes and of fyres with reede leemes
Of rede beestes þat wollen hem byte
Of Contyke and of whelpes grete ⁊and lyte
Riȝt as þe humoure malycolie
Causith many aman in slepe to crye
For fere of Beres and bullys blake
Or elles blak develys wol hir take
Of othere humours couthe I telle also
Þat werken many a man in slepe full woo
But I wolle passe as lyȝtly as I can
Loo Caton whiche þat was so wyse a man
Sayde he not þus ne do no force of dremes
Nou sir qd she when we fle fro þe Bemes
For goddes loue as taketh some laxatyf
Vp peryl of my saule ⁊and of my mete
I counsell you þe beest I wil not lye
Þat both of Colour and of Malencoly
Ȝe purge ȝowe and for ye shul not tarye
Þouȝe þat in þis toune ys none appotecary
I shal my selfe two herbes techen you
þat shal be ȝoure hele and your prowe ¶The Nıı̄unne ~
And in þe Gardyn two herbes shall I fynde
Þe which han of hir ꝓproperte be kynde
To purgen you byneth ⁊and eke a boue
For yeteth nouȝt þis for goddes owen loue
Ye ben fulle colrik of complexioıı̄un
Where þe sonne in his ascencioıı̄un
Ne fynde you replete of your humours hoot
And if it do I dar wele lay a grote
Þat she shal haue a fever tarsyan
Or an agu þat may be your bane
A day or two ye shalle haue digestyues
Of wormes or ye take your laxatyues
Of laure al Centaure and of fumyter
Or elles of Ellebore þat groweth þere
Of Catapuce or of gaytes buries
Of Erbe yve growynge in our yerd þ̉er/ree mery ys
Pek hem vp riȝt as þei growe ⁊and ete hem In
Be mery husbond for your fadre kyn
Dredeth nodreme I can say you no more
Ma dame qd he Gromercy of yoᵘur lore
But nathles as touchynge Daun Catoıı̄un
Þat hath of wisdom suche grete rennoıı̄un
Be god men may in old bokes rede
On of þe grettest auctor of drede
Of many a man more of auctorite
Þan euere Caton was so mot I the
Þat alle þe reuerse sayne of þis sentence
And han wele founde by experience
Þat dremes ben significacioıı̄uns
As wele of Ioye as of tribulacions
Þat folke enduren in þis lyf present
Þere nedeth not to make of þis none argument
The verray preef sheweth it in dede
On of þe grettest auctour of drede
Saith þus þat whilom two felawes went
Of pilgrymage in fulle gode entent ¶Prest
And happed so þe comen in to a toun
Where as þere was suche congrecacioıı̄un
Of peple and eke of streit herbygage
Þat þei fand as moche as a Cotage
In whiche þei both myȝt y logged be
Wherfore þei mosten of necessite
As for þat nyȝt departen of companye
And eche of hem goth into hir Ostelerie
And toke hys loggynge as hit wolde falle
Þat on of hem was logged in a stalle
Ferre in a yerd with oxen of þe ploghe
Þat oþer man was logged wele ynouȝe
As was hys auenture or his fortune
Þat vs governeth al as in comune
And so be felle longe or hit were day
Þis man mette in hys bedde þere as he lay
How þat his felawe gan on hy calle
